page.title: 01Barningham Moor
page.content: The area slopes down from the south, about 240m. A broad band of treeless moorland stretches from SW to NE, devoted to Swalesdale sheep farming and grouse shooting. The NW corner includes the east end of the Stang forest (forestry commission) and the Birch clothed Woodclose Gill. The remainder is mostly improved meadow and pasture farmland enclosed in 1803. The SE corner is also improved farmland enclosed 1777, a favourite hunting ground of the short eared owl. Dry stone walls are a prominant feature especially on the high ground. The remains of activities of bronze age folk e,g, the tumulus How Tallon, and the green pack-horse ways are still conspicuous on the open moorland.
